title: Franson Interferometer for Time-Bin Entanglement
description: Demonstrates energy-time entanglement using unbalanced Mach-Zehnder interferometers in both photon paths with time-bin encoded states

parameters.description: Separates orthogonally polarized signal and idler photons to different spatial modes
Directs signal photons toward signal interferometer
Short arm mirror for signal path
First mirror in long arm for signal path
Second mirror in long arm for signal path
Short arm mirror for idler path
First mirror in long arm for idler path
Second mirror in long arm for idler path
Piezo-controlled phase shifter for signal interference
Piezo-controlled phase shifter for idler interference
Electronic unit processing both SPAD outputs to identify coincidence events and measure two-photon interference visibility

physics_explanation: SPDC creates entangled photon pairs in a superposition of being created at early or late times. The PBS separates orthogonally polarized signal and idler photons into different spatial paths. Each photon passes through an unbalanced Mach-Zehnder interferometer with path length difference ΔL much longer than the coherence length, erasing individual photon interference. However, the time-bin entangled state |ψ⟩ = (|early,early⟩ + e^(iφ)|late,late⟩)/√2 produces two-photon interference visible only in coincidence measurements when both interferometer phase differences are scanned. The narrow-band filters (coherence time > ΔL/c) ensure indistinguishability of the early and late emission times, enabling violation of Bell inequalities and demonstrating energy-time entanglement through the Franson interference pattern.

component_justifications.Pump Laser: 405nm CW pump laser for continuous SPDC generation with moderate linewidth to create energy-time entangled photon pairs
component_justifications.PPLN Crystal: Periodically-poled lithium niobate crystal for efficient Type-II SPDC, generating orthogonally polarized signal and idler photons at 810nm with energy-time entanglement
component_justifications.PBS Separator: Polarizing beam splitter separates Type-II SPDC signal (H-polarized) and idler (V-polarized) photons into different spatial modes for independent interferometers
component_justifications.Mirror to Signal Arm: Redirects H-polarized signal photons upward to the signal interferometer path
component_justifications.BS1 Signal: First 50:50 beam splitter in signal arm creates superposition of short and long paths (time bins)
component_justifications.BS1 Idler: First 50:50 beam splitter in idler arm creates superposition of short and long paths (time bins)
component_justifications.Mirror S-Short: Reflects signal photon in short arm of signal interferometer
component_justifications.Mirror S-Long-1: First mirror directing signal photon through extended long arm for time delay
component_justifications.Mirror S-Long-2: Second mirror in long arm returning signal photon to recombination beam splitter
component_justifications.Mirror I-Short: Reflects idler photon in short arm of idler interferometer
component_justifications.Mirror I-Long-1: First mirror directing idler photon through extended long arm for time delay
component_justifications.Mirror I-Long-2: Second mirror in long arm returning idler photon to recombination beam splitter
component_justifications.BS2 Signal: Second 50:50 beam splitter recombines short and long paths in signal interferometer
component_justifications.BS2 Idler: Second 50:50 beam splitter recombines short and long paths in idler interferometer
component_justifications.Phase Shifter Signal: Piezo-mounted mirror or phase modulator to scan relative phase φ_S between signal interferometer arms
component_justifications.Phase Shifter Idler: Piezo-mounted mirror or phase modulator to scan relative phase φ_I between idler interferometer arms
component_justifications.Filter Signal: Narrow-band interference filter (3nm bandwidth) increases coherence time to exceed path delay, making early/late emission times indistinguishable
component_justifications.Filter Idler: Narrow-band interference filter (3nm bandwidth) increases coherence time to exceed path delay, making early/late emission times indistinguishable
component_justifications.SPAD Signal: Single-photon avalanche photodiode with sub-nanosecond timing resolution for detecting signal photons and providing electrical timing signals
component_justifications.SPAD Idler: Single-photon avalanche photodiode with sub-nanosecond timing resolution for detecting idler photons and providing electrical timing signals
component_justifications.Coincidence Counter: Time-tagging electronics receives electrical signals from both SPADs to measure coincidence counts as function of phase settings, revealing two-photon interference pattern characteristic of energy-time entanglement

expected_outcome: When scanning both phase shifters, coincidence counts show sinusoidal interference pattern with visibility V > 70% (ideally approaching 1/√2 ≈ 71% for maximally entangled state). Single detector counts show no interference (flat). Maximum coincidences occur when φ_S + φ_I = 0, minimum at φ_S + φ_I = π. Violation of Bell inequality (S > 2) confirms energy-time entanglement. The path length difference should be ~30cm (1ns delay), much longer than pump coherence length (~300μm) but shorter than filtered photon coherence length (~100mm with 3nm filter).
